DOC.HEAD: AP Reporter Wounded in Romanian Upheaval
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Correspondent John Daniszewski was shot and wounded by a group of uniformed men who stopped his car and was in satisfactory condition in a Timisoara hospital Sunday, the Yugoslav Consulate said. The consulate, in a telephone call to the AP's Belgrade bureau, said Daniszewski's wounds were not life-threatening. One bullet entered his arm above the elbow before exiting at his shoulder, and two more grazed his head, said the consulate, adding that he was at Judecian hospital in Timisoara. Daniszewski, a correspondent based in Warsaw, Poland, was in the Romanian city about 30 miles east of the Yugoslav border to cover the revolution in Romania. The consulate said it was informed about the shooting and Daniszewski's condition by Ljuba Pajic, a Yugoslav journalist working for the Politika Expres newspaper, who was with him in the car. The two were ordered stopped Saturday night by a group of men in uniform _ either soldiers or men belonging to deposed President Nicolae Ceauescu's special police, which is resisting revolutionaries backed by the army. As Daniszewski was braking, the group fired at the car, said Pajic, who was unhurt. They subsequently robbed the two of their belongings. Daniszewski was driven to hospital by a carload of Yugoslav journalists.
